elements.content: Flexible luminescent metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) sensitive to physical and chemical variation demonstrate potential application in sensing, but are commonly limited to ones incorporating specialized chromophores, so that the design, preparation, and reversible well-defined crystallographic transitions of such materials remain a great challenge. Here, an easily prepared flexible luminescent silver-chalcogenolate cluster-based metal–organic framework (SCC-MOF), Ag 10 bpy, exceptionally distinguishes chloromethanes CH2Cl2, CHCl3, and CCl4 by different fluorescent responsive signals, which originated from its crystalline dipole moment orientation relative to chromophores. Moreover, “glass-to-fluid” transition of the distinctly responsive species in the crystalline pore is demonstrated to modulate striking chromism with scarce segmented emission among MOFs, resulting from subtle dynamic solvation of chromophores. Retention of single crystallinity enables elucidation of the relationship between distinct fluorescent response and complicated structural variation at the molecular level. This new type of flexible emissive SCC-MOF is potentially useful for the development of versatile sensing and switching fluorescent materials.
elements.clean_text: Flexible luminescent metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) sensitive to physical and chemical variation demonstrate potential application in sensing, but are commonly limited to ones incorporating specialized chromophores, so that the design, preparation, and reversible well-defined crystallographic transitions of such materials remain a great challenge. Here, an easily prepared flexible luminescent silver-chalcogenolate cluster-based metal-organic framework (SCC-MOF), Ag  10  bpy, exceptionally distinguishes chloromethanes CH2Cl2, CHCl3, and CCl4 by different fluorescent responsive signals, which originated from its crystalline dipole moment orientation relative to chromophores. Moreover, "glass-to-fluid" transition of the distinctly responsive species in the crystalline pore is demonstrated to modulate striking chromism with scarce segmented emission among MOFs, resulting from subtle dynamic solvation of chromophores. Retention of single crystallinity enables elucidation of the relationship between distinct fluorescent response and complicated structural variation at the molecular level. This new type of flexible emissive SCC-MOF is potentially useful for the development of versatile sensing and switching fluorescent materials.

elements.content: Flexible metal–organic frameworks (MOFs; also known as porous coordination polymers, PCPs), which exhibit unique responsive deformation to environmental stimuli that can afford bi- or multistable states with variable pore sizes, have been demonstrated to be useful for the storage and separation of a target gas in recent years. Luminescent MOFs have demonstrated uniqueness in sensing, which mainly focus on emissive lanthanide and mostly possess relatively rigid frameworks. By contrast, those incorporating non-lanthanide emissive clusters as nodes are less studied. Several flexible luminescent MOFs based on organic moieties demonstrated outstanding sensing ability. However, distinguishing minute structural differences in analytes and directly observing their position and configuration in the cavity of a flexible MOF by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) still pose great challenges, as such capability demands the design of adaptable frameworks incorporating efficient and highly sensitive chromophores, and perfect single crystallinity is commonly lost in most sensing applications for flexible MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Flexible metal-organic frameworks (MOFs; also known as porous coordination polymers, PCPs), which exhibit unique responsive deformation to environmental stimuli that can afford bi- or multistable states with variable pore sizes, have been demonstrated to be useful for the storage and separation of a target gas in recent years. Luminescent MOFs have demonstrated uniqueness in sensing, which mainly focus on emissive lanthanide and mostly possess relatively rigid frameworks. By contrast, those incorporating non-lanthanide emissive clusters as nodes are less studied. Several flexible luminescent MOFs based on organic moieties demonstrated outstanding sensing ability. However, distinguishing minute structural differences in analytes and directly observing their position and configuration in the cavity of a flexible MOF by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) still pose great challenges, as such capability demands the design of adaptable frameworks incorporating efficient and highly sensitive chromophores, and perfect single crystallinity is commonly lost in most sensing applications for flexible MOFs.

elements.content: Dynamics of solvent is known as a core factor in various physical chemistry processes. Solvation dynamics that enables solvent molecules to relax in response to the photoexcitation of a fluorophore can be reflected by the emission variation of simple complexes bearing isolated chromophores in bulk solvents. However, precise investigations on the complicated dynamic solvation process at the molecular level in a crystalline complex combined with observable photoluminescence signal remain a great challenge. A flexible fluorescent MOF not only provides variable pores or cavities to accommodate solvent species, but flexing of the framework also results in a large-size structural change coincident with a high-contrast signal variation for easy readout; the uniqueness is favorable to understand the specific solvent–solute interaction and detect the dynamics of solvation.
elements.clean_text: Dynamics of solvent is known as a core factor in various physical chemistry processes. Solvation dynamics that enables solvent molecules to relax in response to the photoexcitation of a fluorophore can be reflected by the emission variation of simple complexes bearing isolated chromophores in bulk solvents. However, precise investigations on the complicated dynamic solvation process at the molecular level in a crystalline complex combined with observable photoluminescence signal remain a great challenge. A flexible fluorescent MOF not only provides variable pores or cavities to accommodate solvent species, but flexing of the framework also results in a large-size structural change coincident with a high-contrast signal variation for easy readout; the uniqueness is favorable to understand the specific solvent-solute interaction and detect the dynamics of solvation.

elements.content: Silver-chalcogenolate cluster-based MOFs (SCC-MOFs), a new family in which the SCC nodes are extended into networks by organic linkers, have been developed to overcome the instability of SCCs and extend their luminescent application. Flexible SCC-MOFs have not been explored and are expected to produce more novel or unexpected physical and chemical stimuli-responsive functionality, due to the combination of flexibility-related advantages like dynamic frameworks and induced-fit pores, the excellent inherent luminescence functionality of frameworks, and all kinds of charge transfer processes.
elements.clean_text: Silver-chalcogenolate cluster-based MOFs (SCC-MOFs), a new family in which the SCC nodes are extended into networks by organic linkers, have been developed to overcome the instability of SCCs and extend their luminescent application. Flexible SCC-MOFs have not been explored and are expected to produce more novel or unexpected physical and chemical stimuli-responsive functionality, due to the combination of flexibility-related advantages like dynamic frameworks and induced-fit pores, the excellent inherent luminescence functionality of frameworks, and all kinds of charge transfer processes.

elements.content: Here, we report a hydrogen-bonded pillared-layered SCC-MOF, [Ag10(S t Bu)6(CF3COO)2­(Ph­PO3H)2­(bpy)2] n (Ag 10 ­bpy) (bpy = 4,4′-bi­pyri­dine), by introducing a multidentate phenylphosphonic acid (Ph­PO3­H2) ligand as a functional hydrogen-bond donor. The adsorption-induced dynamic gate-opening process, along with obvious solvatochromism, allowed us to clearly distinguish chloromethanes (CH2Cl2, CHCl3, CCl4) by their distinctly different visible luminescence color. More importantly, the temperature-controlled solvation dynamics in the nanocavity of the open phase that accommodated guest species considerably tuned the excited state and resulted in scarce segmented emission for specific temperature-related display among MOFs. This dynamic structure–luminescence relationship was revealed at the molecule level via precise SCXRD combined with vapor adsorption and in situ PL, PXRD as well as density functional theory (DFT) calculations.
elements.clean_text: Here, we report a hydrogen-bonded pillared-layered SCC-MOF, [Ag10(S t Bu)6(CF3COO)2(PhPO3H)2(bpy)2] n  (Ag  10  bpy) (bpy = 4,4'-bipyridine), by introducing a multidentate phenylphosphonic acid (PhPO3H2) ligand as a functional hydrogen-bond donor. The adsorption-induced dynamic gate-opening process, along with obvious solvatochromism, allowed us to clearly distinguish chloromethanes (CH2Cl2, CHCl3, CCl4) by their distinctly different visible luminescence color. More importantly, the temperature-controlled solvation dynamics in the nanocavity of the open phase that accommodated guest species considerably tuned the excited state and resulted in scarce segmented emission for specific temperature-related display among MOFs. This dynamic structure-luminescence relationship was revealed at the molecule level via precise SCXRD combined with vapor adsorption and in situ PL, PXRD as well as density functional theory (DFT) calculations.

elements.content: Room-temperature reaction of CF3COOAg and AgS t Bu in a mixed EtOH–acetone solution with subsequent addition of phenylphosphonic acid and bpy yielded colorless block-like crystals, which were then air-dried to afford Ag 10 bpy. SCXRD analysis of Ag 10 bpy (100 K) revealed that (space group P1̅) each [Ag10(S t Bu)6] cluster core (a and S1) is connected by four bpy linkers at the vertices of Ag6 parallelograms, resulting in a layered architecture with rhombic grids in the ab plane (b and S2). Two hydrogen-bonded PhPO3H linkers are each ligated to a short side of the Ag6 parallelogram. The formation of pairs of complementary strong O–H···O (H···O 1.750 Å) hydrogen bonds between the intercluster PhPO3H linkers (b) and weak C–H···O interactions between interlayer pyridine and CF3COO– groups (Figure S2) lead to the layers stacking in a staggered A-B manner to form a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular structure (b and S2), where grids stack over each other in an offset fashion to yield the closed-porous phase with 9.6% void space. Such a hydrogen-bonded pillared-layered structure with a 2D-grid subnetwork is an important subclass of flexible MOFs to provide dynamic pores, as the layers can slide over each other using hydrogen bonding pillars as “supramolecular glue’’.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses and Characterization

Room-temperature reaction of CF3COOAg and AgS t Bu in a mixed EtOH-acetone solution with subsequent addition of phenylphosphonic acid and bpy yielded colorless block-like crystals, which were then air-dried to afford Ag  10  bpy. SCXRD analysis of Ag  10  bpy (100 K) revealed that (space group P1̅) each [Ag10(S t Bu)6] cluster core (a and S1) is connected by four bpy linkers at the vertices of Ag6 parallelograms, resulting in a layered architecture with rhombic grids in the ab plane (b and S2). Two hydrogen-bonded PhPO3H linkers are each ligated to a short side of the Ag6 parallelogram. The formation of pairs of complementary strong O-H⋅⋅⋅O (H⋅⋅⋅O 1.750 Å) hydrogen bonds between the intercluster PhPO3H linkers (b) and weak C-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions between interlayer pyridine and CF3COO- groups (Figure S2) lead to the layers stacking in a staggered A-B manner to form a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular structure (b and S2), where grids stack over each other in an offset fashion to yield the closed-porous phase with 9.6% void space. Such a hydrogen-bonded pillared-layered structure with a 2D-grid subnetwork is an important subclass of flexible MOFs to provide dynamic pores, as the layers can slide over each other using hydrogen bonding pillars as "supramolecular glue''.

elements.content: (a) Perspective view of the coordination environment of the Ag10(S t Bu)6 core in Ag 10 bpy (100 K). (b) Two-layer stack of the host framework of Ag 10 bpy with complementary hydrogen bonding (O–H···O, H···O distance is 1.750 Å) between interlayer −PO2OH moieties.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Perspective view of the coordination environment of the Ag10(S t Bu)6 core in Ag  10  bpy (100 K). (b) Two-layer stack of the host framework of Ag  10  bpy with complementary hydrogen bonding (O-H⋅⋅⋅O, H⋅⋅⋅O distance is 1.750 Å) between interlayer -PO2OH moieties.

elements.content: The TG plot showed that no weight loss occurred under 120 °C (Figure S3), suggesting the solvents (ethanol and acetone) used in preparing Ag 10 bpy are not left in its cavity via air-drying. The consistence between these patterns between the simulated and experimental PXRD patterns demonstrated the phase purity of as-prepared Ag 10 bpy (Figure S4). The elemental analysis results (%) for Ag 10 bpy is also consistent with the calculated. Its green emission in air can be clearly seen by the naked eye, with an emission maximum at 518 nm (excited at 365 nm) (, S5, and S6), which was tentatively assigned to a cluster nodes to ligands (bpy) charge transfer (CT) transition, accroding to the DFT calculation results (Figure S7).

The consistence between these patterns between the simulated and experimental PXRD patterns demonstrated the phase purity of as-prepared Ag  10  bpy (Figure S4). The elemental analysis results (%) for Ag  10  bpy is also consistent with the calculated. Its green emission in air can be clearly seen by the naked eye, with an emission maximum at 518 nm (excited at 365 nm) (, S5, and S6), which was tentatively assigned to a cluster nodes to ligands (bpy) charge transfer (CT) transition, accroding to the DFT calculation results (Figure S7).

elements.content: (a) Sorption (filled symbols) and desorption (empty symbols) isotherms for Ag 10 bpy with N2 (77 K) and CO2 (195 K). (b) The gate-opening adsorption of CH2Cl2, CHCl3, and CHCl4 for Ag 10 bpy at room temperature. (c) The structures of chloromethanes and their lumininescent responsive images (excited at 365 nm). (d) Normalized PL spectra of closed-phase Ag 10 bpy and Ag 10 bpy upon exposure to CH2Cl2, CCl4, and CHCl3 excited at 365 nm. (e) PL spectra of Ag 10 bpy at various vapor pressures (P/P 0 = 0–1) of CHCl3 at room temperature and luminescent images of single crystals. (f) The maximum emission peak (red) and normalized PL intensity (green) in (d) and adsorption plot (blue) as a function of CHCl3 vapor pressure.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Sorption (filled symbols) and desorption (empty symbols) isotherms for Ag  10  bpy with N2 (77 K) and CO2 (195 K). (b) The gate-opening adsorption of CH2Cl2, CHCl3, and CHCl4 for Ag  10  bpy at room temperature. (c) The structures of chloromethanes and their lumininescent responsive images (excited at 365 nm). (d) Normalized PL spectra of closed-phase Ag  10  bpy and Ag  10  bpy upon exposure to CH2Cl2, CCl4, and CHCl3 excited at 365 nm. (e) PL spectra of Ag  10  bpy at various vapor pressures (P/P 0 = 0-1) of CHCl3 at room temperature and luminescent images of single crystals. (f) The maximum emission peak (red) and normalized PL intensity (green) in (d) and adsorption plot (blue) as a function of CHCl3 vapor pressure.

elements.content: To examine the dynamic processes in Ag 10 bpy, we first performed adsorption measurements for gases and volatile solvents (a,b). The gas sorption isotherms showed almost negligible N2 adsorption at 77 K and normal CO2 adsorption at 195 K, which are similar to those in other ultra-microporous materials. Stepwise sigmoidal adsorption isotherms for CHCl3, CH2Cl2 vapor also indicate the important breathing or gate-opening behavior, in which the maximum adsorption corresponds to four guest molecules per asymmetric unit, while CCl4 is adsorbed to a lesser extent (b). For CHCl3, an initial gradual uptake (0.15 mmol·g–1), then a transitory constant uptake from P/P 0 = 0.15 to 0.25, and subsequently a sharp increase before finally reaching 3.35 mmol·g–1 at P/P 0 = 0.82, were observed (b). The obvious hysteresis suggests that guest molecules are trapped within the channels and released only at relatively low pressures, indicating the existence of dynamic framework breathing behavior.
elements.clean_text:
Gate-Opening Effect and Chloromethanes Identification

To examine the dynamic processes in Ag  10  bpy, we first performed adsorption measurements for gases and volatile solvents (a,b). The gas sorption isotherms showed almost negligible N2 adsorption at 77 K and normal CO2 adsorption at 195 K, which are similar to those in other ultra-microporous materials. Stepwise sigmoidal adsorption isotherms for CHCl3, CH2Cl2 vapor also indicate the important breathing or gate-opening behavior, in which the maximum adsorption corresponds to four guest molecules per asymmetric unit, while CCl4 is adsorbed to a lesser extent (b). For CHCl3, an initial gradual uptake (0.15 mmol⋅g-1), then a transitory constant uptake from P/P 0 = 0.15 to 0.25, and subsequently a sharp increase before finally reaching 3.35 mmol⋅g-1 at P/P 0 = 0.82, were observed (b). The obvious hysteresis suggests that guest molecules are trapped within the channels and released only at relatively low pressures, indicating the existence of dynamic framework breathing behavior.

elements.content: Solvatochromism from green to yellow spanning approximately 50 nm occurred upon exposure of Ag 10 bpy to various solvents (CH2Cl2, CHCl3, CCl4, 1,4-dioxane, cyclohexane, DMAc, acetone; Figure S8). In addition, Ag 10 bpy were hydrophobic and water-resistant (Figures S9–S11), making the solvent vapor sensing free from moisture, and its emission is not sensitive to oxygen (Figure S6) probably because of the nature of closed pores. And it kept the constant structure after solvent sensing (Figures S12–S14); the relative emissive intensity before and after CHCl3 vapor treatment did not display an obvious decrease after cycle tests of 10 times (Figure S15), indicating the reversibility and stability of Ag 10 bpy as a sensor around room temperature. This process was fast and reversible (c,d; Video S1), indicating potential application of differentiating these solvents using a simple luminescent signal readout.
elements.clean_text: Solvatochromism from green to yellow spanning approximately 50 nm occurred upon exposure of Ag  10  bpy to various solvents (CH2Cl2, CHCl3, CCl4, 1,4-dioxane, cyclohexane, DMAc, acetone; Figure S8). In addition, Ag  10  bpy were hydrophobic and water-resistant (Figures S9-S11), making the solvent vapor sensing free from moisture, and its emission is not sensitive to oxygen (Figure S6) probably because of the nature of closed pores. And it kept the constant structure after solvent sensing (Figures S12-S14); the relative emissive intensity before and after CHCl3 vapor treatment did not display an obvious decrease after cycle tests of 10 times (Figure S15), indicating the reversibility and stability of Ag  10  bpy as a sensor around room temperature. This process was fast and reversible (c,d; Video S1), indicating potential application of differentiating these solvents using a simple luminescent signal readout.

elements.content: Notably, three chloro derivatives of methane, namely, CH2Cl2, CHCl3, and CCl4, could be easily distinguished because of their striking difference of luminescent color in visible light: CH2Cl2 displayed no shift (green), CCl4 showed a 15 nm red shift (yellow-green), and CHCl3 displayed the biggest red shift of 52 nm (yellow) (Video S1 and Figure S8). The quantum yield ΦPL,  Ag10bpy is observed to be 0.21%; for CH2Cl2, CHCl3, CCl4, and the photoluminescent quantum yields (ΦPL) are correspondingly enhanced: ΦPL,  Ag10bpy·solvents /ΦPL,  Ag10bpy are equal to 11.24, 62.79, 1.57, respectively. To the best of our knowledge, Ag 10 bpy represents a rare luminescent flexible MOF to easily and simultaneously distinguish CH2Cl2, CHCl3, and CCl4. It is a pity that quantifying the mixtures (CHCl3 and CCl4) is difficult, although the single-component adsorption of them is different (Figure S16). In general, only one chloromethane produced different vapochromism, while the other two cannot be simultaneously discriminated in other reported sensors. Surprisingly, this unprecedented chemoresponsive luminescence of these chloromethanes seriously deviated from the trend of the dielectric constant and solvent polarity order (CH2Cl2 > CHCl3 > CCl4 on the E T(30) scale), which are common criteria for evaluating the interaction of solvent–chromophores. Then, where does the abnormal performance originate from? How do the chloromethanes interact with the framework of flexible SCC-MOF?
elements.clean_text: Notably, three chloro derivatives of methane, namely, CH2Cl2, CHCl3, and CCl4, could be easily distinguished because of their striking difference of luminescent color in visible light: CH2Cl2 displayed no shift (green), CCl4 showed a 15 nm red shift (yellow-green), and CHCl3 displayed the biggest red shift of 52 nm (yellow) (Video S1 and Figure S8). The quantum yield ΦPL,  Ag10bpy   is observed to be 0.21%; for CH2Cl2, CHCl3, CCl4, and the photoluminescent quantum yields (ΦPL) are correspondingly enhanced: ΦPL,  Ag10bpy⋅solvents  /ΦPL,  Ag10bpy   are equal to 11.24, 62.79, 1.57, respectively. To the best of our knowledge, Ag  10  bpy represents a rare luminescent flexible MOF to easily and simultaneously distinguish CH2Cl2, CHCl3, and CCl4. It is a pity that quantifying the mixtures (CHCl3 and CCl4) is difficult, although the single-component adsorption of them is different (Figure S16). In general, only one chloromethane produced different vapochromism, while the other two cannot be simultaneously discriminated in other reported sensors. Surprisingly, this unprecedented chemoresponsive luminescence of these chloromethanes seriously deviated from the trend of the dielectric constant and solvent polarity order (CH2Cl2 > CHCl3 > CCl4 on the E T(30) scale), which are common criteria for evaluating the interaction of solvent-chromophores. Then, where does the abnormal performance originate from? How do the chloromethanes interact with the framework of flexible SCC-MOF?

elements.content: To gain insight into the origin of considerably different solvatochromism among chloromethanes, we investigated CHCl3- and CH2Cl2-induced structural dynamics and their structure–luminescence correlation in detail, respectively. Room-temperature PL spectra of Ag 10 bpy recorded at different vapor pressures of CHCl3 from P/P 0 = 0 to 1.0 demonstrated a gradual luminescence change (e). From P/P 0 = 0 to 0.2, the emission band of Ag 10 bpy slightly changed from 518 to 524 nm with a simultaneous stepwise increase in intensity (f) and lifetimes (Figure S17, Table S1). Thereafter, both the PL maximum and intensity showed considerable increases until P/P 0 = 0.7, before finally reaching stable values. In addition, the observed PL variation closely follows the pattern of adsorption progress (f), implying that the CHCl3–host interaction opened the pore and locked them into a certain position, allowing gradual strengthening of the host–guest interactions that drastically regulated the emission until adsorption saturation. In contrast, the framework emission peak wavelength showed little dependence on vapor pressure of CH2Cl2.
elements.clean_text: To gain insight into the origin of considerably different solvatochromism among chloromethanes, we investigated CHCl3- and CH2Cl2-induced structural dynamics and their structure-luminescence correlation in detail, respectively. Room-temperature PL spectra of Ag  10  bpy recorded at different vapor pressures of CHCl3 from P/P 0 = 0 to 1.0 demonstrated a gradual luminescence change (e). From P/P 0 = 0 to 0.2, the emission band of Ag  10  bpy slightly changed from 518 to 524 nm with a simultaneous stepwise increase in intensity (f) and lifetimes (Figure S17, Table S1). Thereafter, both the PL maximum and intensity showed considerable increases until P/P 0 = 0.7, before finally reaching stable values. In addition, the observed PL variation closely follows the pattern of adsorption progress (f), implying that the CHCl3-host interaction opened the pore and locked them into a certain position, allowing gradual strengthening of the host-guest interactions that drastically regulated the emission until adsorption saturation. In contrast, the framework emission peak wavelength showed little dependence on vapor pressure of CH2Cl2.

elements.content: To further elucidate the gate-opening process by CH2Cl2 and CHCl3 and examine the possibility of phase transformation, PXRD patterns were recorded at different pressures of CHCl3 and CH2Cl2 vapor from P/P 0 = 0 to 1.0 at intervals of 0.2 (a and S12). For CHCl3, from P/P 0 = 0 to 0.4, the PXRD patterns slightly changed. The diffraction peaks (2θ = 5.405°) below 6° at P/P 0 = 0.6 indexed to the (001) plane appeared, suggesting these closed pores were completely opened by CHCl3 (b), being consistent with the adsorption process of CHCl3 (b) and visualized in the CHCl3-filled crystal structure (Ag 10 bpy·CHCl 3 ) (d). The similar process happened to CH2Cl2 vapor (Figure S12) and other solvents (Figure S13). Slightly differently, the pore dimension of Ag 10 bpy·CH 2 Cl 2 is a little smaller than that of Ag 10 bpy·CHCl 3 ; in other words, the expanded c-axis of the former (17.807 Å) is shorter than that of the latter (18.283 Å) (100 K single crystal data). Thus, the gate-opening process in response to solvent accommodation resulted in change from a nonporous phase (Ag 10 bpy) to a porous phase (Ag 10 bpy·solvent) (c), which can be macroscopically observed by the accompanied PL color and intensity variation (e).
elements.clean_text:
PXRD and SCXRD Analysis of the Gate-Opening Effect and SC-SC Transformation

To further elucidate the gate-opening process by CH2Cl2 and CHCl3 and examine the possibility of phase transformation, PXRD patterns were recorded at different pressures of CHCl3 and CH2Cl2 vapor from P/P 0 = 0 to 1.0 at intervals of 0.2 (a and S12). For CHCl3, from P/P 0 = 0 to 0.4, the PXRD patterns slightly changed. The diffraction peaks (2θ = 5.405°) below 6° at P/P 0 = 0.6 indexed to the (001) plane appeared, suggesting these closed pores were completely opened by CHCl3 (b), being consistent with the adsorption process of CHCl3 (b) and visualized in the CHCl3-filled crystal structure (Ag  10  bpy⋅CHCl  3 ) (d). The similar process happened to CH2Cl2 vapor (Figure S12) and other solvents (Figure S13). Slightly differently, the pore dimension of Ag  10  bpy⋅CH  2  Cl  2  is a little smaller than that of Ag  10  bpy⋅CHCl  3 ; in other words, the expanded c-axis of the former (17.807 Å) is shorter than that of the latter (18.283 Å) (100 K single crystal data). Thus, the gate-opening process in response to solvent accommodation resulted in change from a nonporous phase (Ag  10  bpy) to a porous phase (Ag  10  bpy⋅solvent) (c), which can be macroscopically observed by the accompanied PL color and intensity variation (e).

elements.content: (a) PXRD patterns of Ag 10 bpy samples treated with CHCl3 vapor at different partial pressures (P/P 0 = 0–1.0), and simulated Ag 10 bpy·CHCl 3 from the single-crystal data (220 K). (b) The new peak below 6° in (a) corresponds to expansion of the pores, and the highlighted CHCl3 (ball-and-stick mode) packs on or near the (001) plane in the Ag 10 bpy·CHCl 3 crystal structure (220 K). (c) Illustration of CH2Cl2, CHCl3, and CCl4 represented in space-filling mode induced reversible pore-open/closed structural transformation and switchable solvatochromism. (d, e) The vector of net dipole moments (μ) of ground-state CHCl3 and CH2Cl2 point toward respective pyridine ring planes in Ag 10 bpy·CHCl 3 (100 K) and align nearly parallel to the pyridine ring planes in Ag 10 bpy·CH 2 Cl 2 (100 K).
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) PXRD patterns of Ag  10  bpy samples treated with CHCl3 vapor at different partial pressures (P/P 0 = 0-1.0), and simulated Ag  10  bpy⋅CHCl  3  from the single-crystal data (220 K). (b) The new peak below 6° in (a) corresponds to expansion of the pores, and the highlighted CHCl3 (ball-and-stick mode) packs on or near the (001) plane in the Ag  10  bpy⋅CHCl  3  crystal structure (220 K). (c) Illustration of CH2Cl2, CHCl3, and CCl4 represented in space-filling mode induced reversible pore-open/closed structural transformation and switchable solvatochromism. (d, e) The vector of net dipole moments (μ) of ground-state CHCl3 and CH2Cl2 point toward respective pyridine ring planes in Ag  10  bpy⋅CHCl  3  (100 K) and align nearly parallel to the pyridine ring planes in Ag  10  bpy⋅CH  2  Cl  2  (100 K).

elements.content: The well-defined crystallographic characterization of the open- and closed-pore forms induced by solvent, together with direct observation of the guest positions and conformations, provides sufficient visual and convincing evidence for this behavior. However, similar characterizations are quite limited in previously reported flexible fluorescent MOFs. Fortunately, the strong hydrogen-bonded “glue” between the 2D grid layers endows not only dynamic flexibility but also robust tenacity, allowing for the preparation of Ag 10 bpy·CH 2 Cl 2 and Ag 10 bpy·CHCl 3 single crystals via single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SC-SC) transition. This SC-SC transition led to the insight into their crystallographic structures, nature of host–guest interaction, and different origin of solvatochromic response. The 100 K single crystal data for Ag 10 bpy·CHCl 3 showed retention of the original space group P1̅ and metal–ligand connectivity established for Ag 10 bpy, except that the c-axis significantly increased from 14.1960(3) to 18.2826(3) Å, and the volume increased from 2073.96(8) to 2824.76(9) Å3 (Figure S18 and Tables S2, S3). The most notable structural modification is that the junction between the Ag10 cores and bpy ligands changed from a bent form to a stretched form (Figures S19 and S20), which considerably minimizes the degree of overlap of adjacent layers and maximizes the solvent accessible void space from 9.6% to 37.1%. A simplified 4,4-net framework model of the host framework is used to clearly illustrate the reversible pore-open/closed structural transformation and switchable different luminescence responses between green in the closed phase of Ag 10 bpy and various solovochromism in the open phase of Ag 10 bpy·solvents (e and S21). In the interlayer region, weak C–H···O and strong O–H···O hydrogen bonds between two phosphate groups (from 2.558 to 2.595 Å) are only slightly stretched (Figure S22), indicating their contribution to retain crystallinity.
elements.clean_text: The well-defined crystallographic characterization of the open- and closed-pore forms induced by solvent, together with direct observation of the guest positions and conformations, provides sufficient visual and convincing evidence for this behavior. However, similar characterizations are quite limited in previously reported flexible fluorescent MOFs. Fortunately, the strong hydrogen-bonded "glue" between the 2D grid layers endows not only dynamic flexibility but also robust tenacity, allowing for the preparation of Ag  10  bpy⋅CH  2  Cl  2  and Ag  10  bpy⋅CHCl  3  single crystals via single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SC-SC) transition. This SC-SC transition led to the insight into their crystallographic structures, nature of host-guest interaction, and different origin of solvatochromic response. The 100 K single crystal data for Ag  10  bpy⋅CHCl  3  showed retention of the original space group P1̅ and metal-ligand connectivity established for Ag  10  bpy, except that the c-axis significantly increased from 14.1960(3) to 18.2826(3) Å, and the volume increased from 2073.96(8) to 2824.76(9) Å3 (Figure S18 and Tables S2, S3). The most notable structural modification is that the junction between the Ag10 cores and bpy ligands changed from a bent form to a stretched form (Figures S19 and S20), which considerably minimizes the degree of overlap of adjacent layers and maximizes the solvent accessible void space from 9.6% to 37.1%. A simplified 4,4-net framework model of the host framework is used to clearly illustrate the reversible pore-open/closed structural transformation and switchable different luminescence responses between green in the closed phase of Ag  10  bpy and various solovochromism in the open phase of Ag  10  bpy⋅solvents (e and S21). In the interlayer region, weak C-H⋅⋅⋅O and strong O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds between two phosphate groups (from 2.558 to 2.595 Å) are only slightly stretched (Figure S22), indicating their contribution to retain crystallinity.

elements.content: Among the four CHCl3 molecules per asymmetric unit in Ag 10 bpy·CHCl 3 (Figure S18), CHCl3(I) nearest to the bpy linker and CHCl3(II) located at the corner of the square channel are ordered and bound to the host network via a localized Cl···π interaction (the distance between Cl7 and C26 is equal to 3.368 Å) and C–H···O hydrogen bonding, respectively. The other two CHCl3 molecules are disordered at the center of the cavity. Therefore, positive solvatochromism, e.g., the CHCl3-induced red shift of emission at room temperature, is temporarily ascribed to dipole–dipole interactions between CHCl3(I) molecules and the bpy linker chromophores in view of the nature of intermolecular charge transfer transition. Commonly, the dipole moment value serves as a criterion to evaluate solute–solvent interactions, which is however not singly capable of adequate description of these chloromethane complexes in view of the μ (D) values of CH2Cl2 (1.678) > CHCl3 (1.085) > CCl4 (0) based on DFT simulation (B3LYP/aug-cc-pVTZ). Fortunately, the well-defined guest positions and conformations provided more information, as the dipole moment vector (μ) of CHCl3 (d) points to the pyridine ring plane associated with the lowest unoccupied MO (LUMO; Figure S7), which may easily relax and solvate the nearest bpy moieties upon excitation which possess a larger excited-state dipole of intermolecular CT characteristics. As a result, the excited state is better stabilized, and a remarkable red-shifted emission appeared. This solvation process of CHCl3 will be further verified in the temperature-controlled emission studies of Ag 10 bpy·CHCl 3 . In contrast, the CH2Cl2 molecules in Ag 10 bpy·CH 2 Cl 2 (Figure S23) located at the similar positions with CHCl3 in Ag 10 bpy·CHCl 3 cannot interact with the excited bpy chromophores, which was ascribed to the fact that the dipole moment vector (μ) of CH2Cl2 is nearly parallel to the pyridine ring (e), which would require a much higher magnitude of rotation to adapt and relax to the generated excited-state dipole of the chromophores. The dramatic rotation may be too difficult to be accommodated within a crystalline complex, so the dipole–dipole interaction in the emissive spectrum of Ag 10 bpy·CH 2 Cl 2 cannot be clearly observed. Unfortunately, Ag 10 bpy·CCl 4 crystals of good quality for SCXRD analysis cannot be obtained. Despite the absence of inherent dipole for CCl4, instantaneous dipoles resulting from dispersion interactions can lead to bathochromic band shifts (15 nm less than CHCl3-induced 52 nm) because molecules in their electronic excited states possess higher polarizabilities than those in their ground states. Therefore, tiny differences of dipole moment vectors of the confined chloromethane molecules (CH2Cl2, CHCl3, and CCl4) ultimately led to different interaction degrees with the excited-state host framework and thus distinctly different fluorescence responses.
elements.clean_text: Among the four CHCl3 molecules per asymmetric unit in Ag  10  bpy⋅CHCl  3  (Figure S18), CHCl3(I) nearest to the bpy linker and CHCl3(II) located at the corner of the square channel are ordered and bound to the host network via a localized Cl⋅⋅⋅π interaction (the distance between Cl7 and C26 is equal to 3.368 Å) and C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding, respectively. The other two CHCl3 molecules are disordered at the center of the cavity. Therefore, positive solvatochromism, e.g., the CHCl3-induced red shift of emission at room temperature, is temporarily ascribed to dipole-dipole interactions between CHCl3(I) molecules and the bpy linker chromophores in view of the nature of intermolecular charge transfer transition. Commonly, the dipole moment value serves as a criterion to evaluate solute-solvent interactions, which is however not singly capable of adequate description of these chloromethane complexes in view of the μ (D) values of CH2Cl2 (1.678) > CHCl3 (1.085) > CCl4 (0) based on DFT simulation (B3LYP/aug-cc-pVTZ). Fortunately, the well-defined guest positions and conformations provided more information, as the dipole moment vector (μ) of CHCl3 (d) points to the pyridine ring plane associated with the lowest unoccupied MO (LUMO; Figure S7), which may easily relax and solvate the nearest bpy moieties upon excitation which possess a larger excited-state dipole of intermolecular CT characteristics. As a result, the excited state is better stabilized, and a remarkable red-shifted emission appeared. This solvation process of CHCl3 will be further verified in the temperature-controlled emission studies of Ag  10  bpy⋅CHCl  3 . In contrast, the CH2Cl2 molecules in Ag  10  bpy⋅CH  2  Cl  2  (Figure S23) located at the similar positions with CHCl3 in Ag  10  bpy⋅CHCl  3  cannot interact with the excited bpy chromophores, which was ascribed to the fact that the dipole moment vector (μ) of CH2Cl2 is nearly parallel to the pyridine ring (e), which would require a much higher magnitude of rotation to adapt and relax to the generated excited-state dipole of the chromophores. The dramatic rotation may be too difficult to be accommodated within a crystalline complex, so the dipole-dipole interaction in the emissive spectrum of Ag  10  bpy⋅CH  2  Cl  2  cannot be clearly observed. Unfortunately, Ag  10  bpy⋅CCl  4  crystals of good quality for SCXRD analysis cannot be obtained. Despite the absence of inherent dipole for CCl4, instantaneous dipoles resulting from dispersion interactions can lead to bathochromic band shifts (15 nm less than CHCl3-induced 52 nm) because molecules in their electronic excited states possess higher polarizabilities than those in their ground states. Therefore, tiny differences of dipole moment vectors of the confined chloromethane molecules (CH2Cl2, CHCl3, and CCl4) ultimately led to different interaction degrees with the excited-state host framework and thus distinctly different fluorescence responses.

elements.content: In this case, the conformation of confined solvents resulted in such distinct luminescence, and their slight motion with temperature may vary the interaction with the host framework and tune the emitting luminescence. We then performed the variable-temperature (VT) (83–293 K) steady-state emission for Ag 10 bpy·CHCl 3 which demonstrated that the emission maximum first exhibited a 12 nm hypochromatic shift (534 to 522 nm) from 83 to 163 K (the first segment), and then a 57 nm bathochromic shift (522 to 579 nm) until 213 K (the second segment), along with a corresponding color change from bright green (163 K) through yellow-green of different level bright yellow (213 K) (a,b) (a slight difference from the concentration-dependent emission resulted from different testing conditions). The unique solvent dynamics-regulating temperature display is the first case among flexible MOFs. Above 220 K, the emission maximum gradually restored to the room-temperature 570 nm (the third segment). Similar VT segmented emission was observed for other solvents including acetone and DMAc (Figures S24 and S25). We found that the turning point all lies around the melting point of these included solvents. Therefore, we associated it with medium effects on charge transfer in metal complexes, though the solvents are confined in the cavity. And DSC (differential scanning calorimetry) measurements displayed an endothermic peak at −64.7 °C (208.6 K) during the heating scan (Figure S26), which is close to the turning point (213 K) of luminescence (c), probably representing the melting and the complete freedom of chloroform solvents trapped inside the framework channels.
elements.clean_text:
Temperature Modulating Solvation Dynamics and Emission of Ag  10  bpy⋅CHCl  3  

In this case, the conformation of confined solvents resulted in such distinct luminescence, and their slight motion with temperature may vary the interaction with the host framework and tune the emitting luminescence. We then performed the variable-temperature (VT) (83-293 K) steady-state emission for Ag  10  bpy⋅CHCl  3  which demonstrated that the emission maximum first exhibited a 12 nm hypochromatic shift (534 to 522 nm) from 83 to 163 K (the first segment), and then a 57 nm bathochromic shift (522 to 579 nm) until 213 K (the second segment), along with a corresponding color change from bright green (163 K) through yellow-green of different level bright yellow (213 K) (a,b) (a slight difference from the concentration-dependent emission resulted from different testing conditions). The unique solvent dynamics-regulating temperature display is the first case among flexible MOFs. Above 220 K, the emission maximum gradually restored to the room-temperature 570 nm (the third segment). Similar VT segmented emission was observed for other solvents including acetone and DMAc (Figures S24 and S25). We found that the turning point all lies around the melting point of these included solvents. Therefore, we associated it with medium effects on charge transfer in metal complexes, though the solvents are confined in the cavity. And DSC (differential scanning calorimetry) measurements displayed an endothermic peak at -64.7 °C (208.6 K) during the heating scan (Figure S26), which is close to the turning point (213 K) of luminescence (c), probably representing the melting and the complete freedom of chloroform solvents trapped inside the framework channels.

elements.content: (a, b) 100 K photoluminescence spectra of Ag 10 bpy and Ag 10 bpy·CHCl 3 (83–293 K) under 365 nm excitation. (c) Emission peak maxima of the PL spectra of Ag 10 bpy·CHCl 3 (purple line) and Ag 10 bpy (green line) as a function of temperature. Insets: photoluminescence images of Ag 10 bpy and Ag 10 bpy·CHCl 3 at different temperatures.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a, b) 100 K photoluminescence spectra of Ag  10  bpy and Ag  10  bpy⋅CHCl  3  (83-293 K) under 365 nm excitation. (c) Emission peak maxima of the PL spectra of Ag  10  bpy⋅CHCl  3  (purple line) and Ag  10  bpy (green line) as a function of temperature. Insets: photoluminescence images of Ag  10  bpy and Ag  10  bpy⋅CHCl  3  at different temperatures.

elements.content: In comparison, solvent-free Ag 10 bpy and Ag 10 bpy·CH 2 Cl 2 , which have no efficient host–guest interaction in the excited states, only showed typical nonradiative decay with increasing temperature and a monotonically gradual blue shift (Ag 10 bpy from 534 to 518 nm; Ag 10 bpy·CH 2 Cl 2 from 541 to 518 nm) from 83 to 293 K ( and S27), which appeared in the first segment (83 to 163 K) for Ag 10 bpy·CHCl 3 (c); however, the change of slope rate is larger in Ag 10 bpy·CHCl 3 than that in Ag 10 bpy (c). These hypochromic shifts with temperature increasing are ascribed to elongation of the Ag···Ag distance, as determined by the SCXRD data (Tables S2–S4), resulting in a larger cluster node-to-bpy energy gap. The effect can be denoted as “structural induction”. In addition, the near overlap of the PL spectral profiles of Ag 10 bpy with and without chloromethanes (Figure S28) at 83 K showed that host framework deformation induced by guests did not influence the nature of the charge transfer transition and hardly varied the emission band gap. For the first segment of Ag 10 bpy·CHCl 3 (below 160 K), the solvent molecules may be in a frozen glass state and essentially locked into the equilibrium structure appropriate for the ground state, so that dynamic solvation relaxationsolvent molecules near solute reorienting under the induction of interaction between themcannot occur and play an important role in excited-state dynamics.
elements.clean_text: In comparison, solvent-free Ag  10  bpy and Ag  10  bpy⋅CH  2  Cl  2 , which have no efficient host-guest interaction in the excited states, only showed typical nonradiative decay with increasing temperature and a monotonically gradual blue shift (Ag  10  bpy from 534 to 518 nm; Ag  10  bpy⋅CH  2  Cl  2  from 541 to 518 nm) from 83 to 293 K ( and S27), which appeared in the first segment (83 to 163 K) for Ag  10  bpy⋅CHCl  3  (c); however, the change of slope rate is larger in Ag  10  bpy⋅CHCl  3  than that in Ag  10  bpy (c). These hypochromic shifts with temperature increasing are ascribed to elongation of the Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag distance, as determined by the SCXRD data (Tables S2-S4), resulting in a larger cluster node-to-bpy energy gap. The effect can be denoted as "structural induction". In addition, the near overlap of the PL spectral profiles of Ag  10  bpy with and without chloromethanes (Figure S28) at 83 K showed that host framework deformation induced by guests did not influence the nature of the charge transfer transition and hardly varied the emission band gap. For the first segment of Ag  10  bpy⋅CHCl  3  (below 160 K), the solvent molecules may be in a frozen glass state and essentially locked into the equilibrium structure appropriate for the ground state, so that dynamic solvation relaxationsolvent molecules near solute reorienting under the induction of interaction between themcannot occur and play an important role in excited-state dynamics.

elements.content: The interesting phenomena encourage us to investigate it deeply and explore the temperature-dependent solvent–host interaction. The pronounced red shift in the second segment (163 to 213 K) for Ag 10 bpy·CHCl 3 resulted from the structure-specific solvent–framework interactions in the solvation dynamics, where the solvent molecular motion accompanies excited-state evolution, which are induced by the glass-to-fluid transition of the CHCl3 molecules. That is to say, upon increasing the temperature to 163 K, the frozen CHCl3 molecules at lower temperature would gradually become unfrozen or less rigid and liberate their spatial freedom; then, the solvated complex is allowed to relax to a more stable configuration, resulting in red shift of the emission peak. This process can be called “solvation dynamics induction”, whose contribution is much larger than that of the blue-shifted “structural induction” in the segment; thus the net red shift effect was observed.
elements.clean_text: The interesting phenomena encourage us to investigate it deeply and explore the temperature-dependent solvent-host interaction. The pronounced red shift in the second segment (163 to 213 K) for Ag  10  bpy⋅CHCl  3  resulted from the structure-specific solvent-framework interactions in the solvation dynamics, where the solvent molecular motion accompanies excited-state evolution, which are induced by the glass-to-fluid transition of the CHCl3 molecules. That is to say, upon increasing the temperature to 163 K, the frozen CHCl3 molecules at lower temperature would gradually become unfrozen or less rigid and liberate their spatial freedom; then, the solvated complex is allowed to relax to a more stable configuration, resulting in red shift of the emission peak. This process can be called "solvation dynamics induction", whose contribution is much larger than that of the blue-shifted "structural induction" in the segment; thus the net red shift effect was observed.

elements.content: Variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction (VT PXRD) patterns of Ag 10 bpy·CHCl 3 (a,b and S29) demonstrated that, in the lower angle region from 2θ = 5–10°, the reflections of (001), (011), (100), (101), and (111) lattice planes, which are all present as a result of CHCl3 molecules in the crystal structures (Figures S30–S32), shifted to lower angles over 160 K (a,b), indicating the increased d-spacing with more pore space for movement of the CHCl3 molecules. Correspondingly, VT SCXRD analysis of Ag 10 bpy·CHCl 3 showed an isostructural series (100, 130, 160, 190, 220 K) with slight expansion of unit-cell volume from 2824.77 to 2897.67 Å3 (Table S2). Accompanying the increasing unit-cell parameters, the CHCl3(I) molecules separately bound to the benzene rings of PhPO3H groups (c and S18) gradually loosened their interactions (d), because the distance between carbon and chlorine atoms exceeds the sum of the van der Waals radius over 190 K (d). Therefore, there is a possibility that solvent reorientation and solvation dynamics would occur and stabilize the triplet excited state, when their tiny deformation in the excited state liberated the originally fixed CHCl3(I) (160–220 K), as was demonstrated by DFT calculations (Figure S33). The slight blue shift over 220 K might be resulted from competition of high-temperature-induced fluctuation and relaxation processes and “structural induction”.
elements.clean_text: Variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction (VT PXRD) patterns of Ag  10  bpy⋅CHCl  3  (a,b and S29) demonstrated that, in the lower angle region from 2θ = 5-10°, the reflections of (001), (011), (100), (101), and (111) lattice planes, which are all present as a result of CHCl3 molecules in the crystal structures (Figures S30-S32), shifted to lower angles over 160 K (a,b), indicating the increased d-spacing with more pore space for movement of the CHCl3 molecules. Correspondingly, VT SCXRD analysis of Ag  10  bpy⋅CHCl  3  showed an isostructural series (100, 130, 160, 190, 220 K) with slight expansion of unit-cell volume from 2824.77 to 2897.67 Å3 (Table S2). Accompanying the increasing unit-cell parameters, the CHCl3(I) molecules separately bound to the benzene rings of PhPO3H groups (c and S18) gradually loosened their interactions (d), because the distance between carbon and chlorine atoms exceeds the sum of the van der Waals radius over 190 K (d). Therefore, there is a possibility that solvent reorientation and solvation dynamics would occur and stabilize the triplet excited state, when their tiny deformation in the excited state liberated the originally fixed CHCl3(I) (160-220 K), as was demonstrated by DFT calculations (Figure S33). The slight blue shift over 220 K might be resulted from competition of high-temperature-induced fluctuation and relaxation processes and "structural induction".

elements.content: (a) Comparison of the PXRD patterns of Ag 10 bpy·CHCl 3 at different temperatures. (b) Abrupt increase of d-values of the crystal planes through CHCl3 molecules occurs at 160 K. (c) Cl···π interactions (Cl7···C26) between nearest CHCl3 molecules around the chromophore (bpy) moieties and benzene rings of the PhPO3H groups. (d) Dependence of the temperature from 100 to 220 K on the Cl7···C26 distance (Å) in the single-crystal structures of Ag 10 bpy·CHCl 3 ; the red dotted line represents the sum of the van der Waals radii of interacting atoms Cl7 and C26.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully synthesized a novel flexible SCC-MOF that exhibits a remarkable framework breathing phenomenon upon adsorption of VOCs, being accompanied by distinct responsive fluorescence. Thus, chloromethanes (CH2Cl2, CHCl3, CCl4) were unprecedentedly clearly distinguished by their distinctly different visible luminescence colors using this flexible SCC-MOF sensor. More importantly, solvation dynamics of the included solvent molecules is demonstrated to regulate scarcely temperature-dependent segmented emission among MOFs and lead to striking chromic variation in a narrow temperature range. This work significantly advances the development of flexible late transition metal (Ag, Au, Cu, Pd)-cluster-based metal–organic frameworks for light-emitting materials, chemosensors, and temperature display, and it also offers a new perspective of investigating complicated guest–framework interaction at the molecular level via luminescent SCC-MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have successfully synthesized a novel flexible SCC-MOF that exhibits a remarkable framework breathing phenomenon upon adsorption of VOCs, being accompanied by distinct responsive fluorescence. Thus, chloromethanes (CH2Cl2, CHCl3, CCl4) were unprecedentedly clearly distinguished by their distinctly different visible luminescence colors using this flexible SCC-MOF sensor. More importantly, solvation dynamics of the included solvent molecules is demonstrated to regulate scarcely temperature-dependent segmented emission among MOFs and lead to striking chromic variation in a narrow temperature range. This work significantly advances the development of flexible late transition metal (Ag, Au, Cu, Pd)-cluster-based metal-organic frameworks for light-emitting materials, chemosensors, and temperature display, and it also offers a new perspective of investigating complicated guest-framework interaction at the molecular level via luminescent SCC-MOFs.

cln_elements.content: To examine the dynamic processes in Ag 10 bpy, we first performed adsorption measurements for gases and volatile solvents (a,b). The gas sorption isotherms showed almost negligible N2 adsorption at 77 K and normal CO2 adsorption at 195 K, which are similar to those in other ultra-microporous materials. Stepwise sigmoidal adsorption isotherms for CHCl3, CH2Cl2 vapor also indicate the important breathing or gate-opening behavior, in which the maximum adsorption corresponds to four guest molecules per asymmetric unit, while CCl4 is adsorbed to a lesser extent (b). For CHCl3, an initial gradual uptake (0.15 mmol·g–1), then a transitory constant uptake from P/P 0 = 0.15 to 0.25, and subsequently a sharp increase before finally reaching 3.35 mmol·g–1 at P/P 0 = 0.82, were observed (b). The obvious hysteresis suggests that guest molecules are trapped within the channels and released only at relatively low pressures, indicating the existence of dynamic framework breathing behavior.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Gate-Opening Effect and Chloromethanes Identification

To examine the dynamic processes in Ag  10  bpy, we first performed adsorption measurements for gases and volatile solvents (a,b). The gas sorption isotherms showed almost negligible N2 adsorption at 77 K and normal CO2 adsorption at 195 K, which are similar to those in other ultra-microporous materials. Stepwise sigmoidal adsorption isotherms for CHCl3, CH2Cl2 vapor also indicate the important breathing or gate-opening behavior, in which the maximum adsorption corresponds to four guest molecules per asymmetric unit, while CCl4 is adsorbed to a lesser extent (b). For CHCl3, an initial gradual uptake (0.15 mmol⋅g-1), then a transitory constant uptake from P/P 0 = 0.15 to 0.25, and subsequently a sharp increase before finally reaching 3.35 mmol⋅g-1 at P/P 0 = 0.82, were observed (b). The obvious hysteresis suggests that guest molecules are trapped within the channels and released only at relatively low pressures, indicating the existence of dynamic framework breathing behavior.

gas adsorption.adsorbed amount: four guest molecules per asymmetric unit

metadata.title:
A Flexible Fluorescent SCC-MOF for Switchable Molecule
Identification and Temperature Display
